Url.Title: Access the Release Notes
Url.Abstract: Access the Release Notes SQL secure is a security analysis solution that identifies SQL Server security violations and ensures security policies are enforced. Find out who has access to what and identify each user’s effective rights across all SQL Server objects. Alert on violations of your corporate policies, monitor changes made to security settings, and provide security audit reports as well as recommendations on how to improve your security model.

Url.Title: Get Started
Url.Abstract: Get Started Use the following checklist to guide you through the process of getting started with SQLsecure.

Url.Title: Upgrade to this release
Url.Abstract: Upgrade to this release You can easily and quickly upgrade to the latest version of SQLsecure. Upgrading will not delete or alter any existing snapshots or policies. For more information about this release, see what’s new.

Url.Title: What is SQLsecure?
Url.Abstract: What is SQLsecure? SQL secure is a security analysis solution that identifies SQL Server security violations and ensures security policies are enforced. Find out who has access to what and identify each user’s effective rights across all SQL Server objects. Alert on violations of your corporate policies, monitor changes made to security settings, and provide security audit reports as well as recommendations on how to improve your security model.

Url.Title: How does SQLsecure help me?
Url.Abstract: How does SQLsecure help me? Because of the many different and complex ways to grant access to SQL Server databases – including server and database roles, Active Directory and local groups, inherited permissions, explicit grants and denies, just to name a few – it is virtually impossible to manually analyze a security model across instances or determine a user’s rights on specific database objects. SQLsecure does this for you, answering the important question “Who can do what, where, and how on my SQL Servers?” SQL secure provides a comprehensive, automated solution for analyzing, monitoring, and reporting on security access rights in SQL Server databases.

Url.Title: How SQLsecure works
Url.Abstract: How SQLsecure works SQLsecure uses a Collector to gather permissions information at scheduled intervals. SQLsecure runs this executable using a SQL Server job. The Collector stores each data set as an audit snapshot in a SQLsecure Repository database. The SQLsecure Console connects to the Repository to view your permissions data.

Url.Title: Using this Documentation
Url.Abstract: Find answers using this documentation The SQLsecure documentation set includes this comprehensive, context-sensitive online Help system as well as additional resources that support you as you install and use the product. You can also search Idera Solutions, available at the Idera Customer Service Portal (www.idera.com/support).

Url.Title: Contacting Idera
Url.Abstract: Contact Idera Please contact us with your questions and comments. We look forward to hearing from you. For support around the world, please contact us or your local partner. For a complete list of our partners, please see our Web site.

Url.Title: Document Conventions
Url.Abstract: Document conventions Idera documentation uses consistent conventions to help you identify items throughout the printed online library.

Url.Title: About Idera
Url.Abstract: About Idera At Idera, we deliver a new generation of tools for managing, administering, and securing your Microsoft Windows Servers, including SQL Server, SharePoint, PowerShell and Microsoft Dynamics. We employ numerous industry experts worldwide who are devoted to bringing proven solutions to you, the administrator. Idera provides solutions that help you ensure server performance and availability and reduce administrative overhead and expense. Our award-winning products install in minutes, configure in hours and deploy worldwide in days. Idera is a Microsoft Gold Certified Partner headquartered in Houston, Texas, with offices in London, UK, Melbourne, Australia, and Sao Paulo, Brazil.

Url.Title: Idera Products
Url.Abstract: Idera products Our tools are engineered to scale - from managing a single server to enterprise deployments with thousands of servers. Idera products combine ease of use with a design that installs in minutes, configure in hours, and deploy worldwide in days. To learn more about Idera products, visit our Web site (http://www.idera.com/Content/Products.aspx).

All other company and product names may be trademarks or registered trademarks of their respective companies. © 2012 Idera, Inc., all rights reserved.

Url.Title: Installation and deployment
Url.Abstract: Installation and deployment You can install and deploy SQLsecure in any sized environment. Learn about the product components and architecture

Url.Title: Product components and architecture
Url.Abstract: Product components and architecture SQLsecure provides a robust, easy-to-use SQL Server audit and reporting solution. Behind a friendly user interface, SQLsecure offers a unique architecture that is both flexible and extremely powerful. SQLsecure fits your environment, no matter how simple or complex.

Url.Title: Product requirements
Url.Abstract: Product requirements You can easily and quickly install SQLsecure on any computer that meets or exceeds the following hardware, software, and permission requirements. Before installing SQLsecure, also review the product components and architecture as well as how the product works.

Url.Title: Ensure FIPS compliance
Url.Abstract: Ensure FIPS compliance You can use SQLsecure to audit and assess your SQL Server security in environments where Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) compliance is required.

Url.Title: How to install SQLsecure
Url.Abstract: How to install SQLsecure This procedure guides you through a typical install of SQLsecure. A typical install sets up all SQLsecure components on the same computer. Use this procedure for first-time installs and evaluation installs.

Url.Title: Configure your deployment
Url.Abstract: Configure your deployment After your initial installation and set up, you may want to perform the following tasks to further customize and streamline your deployment.

Url.Title: Connecting to the SQLsecure Repository
Url.Abstract: Connect to the SQLsecure Repository By default, SQLsecure connects to the Repository when you start the Console. You may need to reconnect to the Repository database under these circumstances:

Url.Title: Set up weak password detection
Url.Abstract: Set up weak password detection Use the Weak Password Detection window to set up how SQLsecure determines and enforces password health. In general, users should not use blank passwords, passwords with common words, or passwords that match a login name.

Url.Title: Register a SQL Server
Url.Abstract: Add server to begin auditing The Register a SQL Server wizard allows you to designate the SQL Server instances that you want SQLsecure to audit. The Register a SQL Server wizard allows you to do the following:

Url.Title: Select a SQL Server
Url.Abstract: Select a SQL Server The Select a SQL Server window allows you to specify the SQL Server instance you want to add to SQLsecure for auditing. Type the location of the SQL Server instance you would like to audit, or click Browse to locate it.

Url.Title: Specify connection credentials
Url.Abstract: Specify connection credentials The Specify Connection Credentials window allows you to designate the credentials that SQLsecure uses to access the SQL Server instance you are adding. You can specify either SQL Server login or Windows account credentials.

Url.Source: ../Content/SQLsecure Help/Select SQL Server Objects to Audit.htm
Url.Title: Select SQL Server objects to audit
Url.Abstract: Select SQL Server objects to audit The Select SQL Server Objects to Audit window allows you to specify the objects about which SQLsecure should collect security information. By default, SQLsecure audits all SQL Server objects.

Url.Title: Schedule snapshots for routine data collection
Url.Abstract: Schedule snapshots for routine data collection The Schedule Snapshots window allows you to choose the best times to collect data from your SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Enable email notification
Url.Abstract: Enable email notification The Configure Email Notification window allows you to configure the way email notifications are sent after a snapshot is collected. You can select to have email notifications sent after a snapshot is collected successfully, or only if there are warnings or errors. You can also select to have email notifications sent depending on the level of the security risks discovered.

Url.Title: Add server to existing policies
Url.Abstract: Add server to existing policies The Add to Policies window allows you to include your newly registered instance to any existing custom policies. This window displays only when you have created policies whose server membership has been explicitly defined. For example, if you created a policy that included only your test SQL Server 2005 instance (rather than, for example, all SQL Server 2005 instances), this window will list that policy and allow you to include the newly registered instance.

Url.Title: Choose to take snapshot now
Url.Abstract: Choose to take snapshot now The Take Snapshot window gives you the option to collect audit data at the end of the registration process. Choose this option when you want to immediately perform a security assessment on the newly registered instance. Note that you can also manually take a snapshot later by selecting Take Snapshot on the Explore Permissions view.

Url.Title: Review registration summary
Url.Abstract: Review registration summary Review the provided summary for the instance you are adding to SQLsecure, and then click Finish. When you finish this wizard, SQLsecure enables auditing on the selected SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Use filters to specify which data is collected
Url.Abstract: Use filters to specify which data is collected SQLsecure uses snapshot filters to control the data collected from your audited SQL Server instances. Each filter rule defines which data, such as permissions on user tables in a specific database, is collected and included in the snapshot.

Url.Title: Using the Add Filter wizard
Url.Abstract: Add new filter The Add Filter wizard allows you to choose the appropriate criteria to use when collecting snapshot information. By default, SQLsecure collects all security information.

Url.Title: Select filter type window
Url.Abstract: Specify filter properties This window allows you to name your filter and give it a description. It is important to give your filter a name you can easily distinguish. For more information, see Use the Add Filter Wizard.

Url.Title: Databases and database objects window
Url.Abstract: Specify databases and objects This window allows you to select which databases you want to audit. Option

Url.Title: Edit filter settings
Url.Abstract: Edit filter settings The Filter Properties window allows you to edit the properties of your snapshot filter. You can edit the name and description of your filter, see when it was last modified, and choose which audit data you want to collect in your snapshots.

Url.Title: Snapshot Summary
Url.Abstract: Use snapshots to collect audit data SQLsecure uses audit snapshots to capture SQL Server user and object permission settings. These snapshots are listed in Explore Permissions tree. A snapshot is a set of audit data that SQLsecure has collected from a specific SQL Server instance. You can configure snapshot filters to select which SQL Server objects you want to audit. You can take snapshots manually, as you need fresh data, or schedule snapshots to be taken at regular intervals.

Url.Title: Take Snapshot
Url.Abstract: Take snapshot To immediately collect a data snapshot (audit a SQL Server instance), right-click the server to audit and select Take Snapshot from the context menu.

Url.Title: Designate a baseline snapshot
Url.Abstract: Designate a baseline snapshot A baseline snapshot will not be deleted in the normal SQLsecure grooming process. To mark a snapshot as a baseline, right-click the snapshot in the Snapshots window, and then select Mark as Baseline. When the confirmation window displays, click OK to continue.

Url.Title: Grooming Snapshots
Url.Abstract: Set snapshot grooming schedule Grooming is the process of deleting audit snapshots from the SQLsecure Repository. Grooming allows you to keep only the permissions data you need for future reporting. SQLsecure allows you to schedule snapshot grooming at the enterprise and at the individual SQL Server instance levels. Keep in mind that baseline snapshots and snapshots associated with saved assessments cannot be groomed.

Url.Title: Explore Permissions
Url.Abstract: Explore Security Settings SQLsecure allows you to view the permission settings of individual users, roles, and objects, at a particular point in time, for each SQL Server instance that has been added to SQLsecure for auditing.

Url.Title: Exploring Object Permissions
Url.Abstract: Explore object permissions Select the Object Permissions tab to explore SQL Server permission information for all database and server objects, as well as the password health of SQL logins.

Url.Title: View database properties
Url.Abstract: View database properties The Database Properties window displays the permissions information associated with the selected database. You can view:

Url.Title: View SQL login properties
Url.Abstract: View SQL login properties Use the Login Properties window to review the SQL login security properties for the selected login as well as its most recent password health.

Url.Title: Exploring Role Permissions
Url.Abstract: Explore role permissions The Role Permissions window allows you to explore SQL Server permission information for specific roles on audited SQL Servers in your enterprise.

Url.Title: Role permissions summary
Url.Abstract: Role permissions summary The Summary tab on the Role Summary tab includes SQL Server permission settings for the role you specified in the Role Permissions search criteria.

Url.Title: Assigned role permissions
Url.Abstract: Assigned role permissions The Assigned Permissions tab lists all the explicitly defined and inherited permissions that apply to calculating the role members' effective permissions. You can view permissions information for the selected role and any parent role to which it belongs.

Url.Title: Effective role permissions
Url.Abstract: Effective role permissions The Effective Permissions tab lists all the effective permissions the selected role has on objects in the target database.

Url.Title: Finding user permissions
Url.Abstract: Explore user permissions The Explore User Permissions window allows you to explore SQL Server permission information for specific users on audited SQL Servers in your enterprise.

Url.Title: Assigned Permissions tab
Url.Abstract: Assigned user permissions The Assigned Permissions tab lists all the explicitly defined permissions that apply to calculating the users effective permissions. This includes groups, roles, and aliases as well as covering permissions available in SQL Server 2005 or later.

Url.Title: Effective Permissions tab
Url.Abstract: Effective user permissions The Effective Permissions tab lists all the effective permissions the user has on server and database objects (contained within the audit filter criteria setup by the user).

Url.Title: Summary tab
Url.Abstract: User permissions summary The Summary tab of the User Permissions Explorer contains SQL Server permission settings for the Windows account or SQL Server login you specified in the User Permissions search criteria.

Url.Title: Select a Windows account
Url.Abstract: Select a Windows account The Select Windows User window lists all the Windows users contained in the snapshot you are exploring. Select the Windows account whose permissions you want to explore, and then click OK.

Url.Title: Select a SQL Server login
Url.Abstract: Select a SQL Server login The Select SQL Server Login window lists all of the SQL logins contained in the snapshot you are exploring. Select the login whose permissions you want to explore, and then click OK.

Url.Title: View all audited servers
Url.Abstract: View all audited servers Use the Audited SQL Servers view to review which SQL Server instances and databases are being audited by SQLsecure.

Url.Title: Working with Audit History
Url.Abstract: View single server summary The Server Summary window allows you to view the following: General SQL Server properties

Url.Title: Viewing snapshots
Url.Abstract: View snapshot summary The Snapshot Summary tab lists statistics and other information about the selected snapshot.

Url.Title: View Windows accounts in snapshot
Url.Abstract: View Windows accounts in snapshot The Windows Accounts tab lists the collected Active Directory users and groups that have permissions on SQL Server objects such as database tables. This tab also displays the associated domain, account name, type, and access information for each account.

Url.Title: View OS Windows accounts in snapshot
Url.Abstract: View OS Windows accounts in snapshot The OS Windows Accounts tab lists the collected Active Directory users and groups that have permissions on OS objects such as registry keys. This tab also displays the associated domain, account name, type, and access information for each account.

Url.Title: Suspect Windows Accounts
Url.Abstract: Identify suspect Windows accounts The Suspect Windows Accounts tab lists the Windows user accounts about which SQLsecure was unable to retrieve information when the snapshot was taken. Windows accounts are Active Directory users and groups that have permissions on SQL Server objects.

Url.Title: Identify suspect OS Windows accounts
Url.Abstract: Identify suspect OS Windows accounts The Suspect OS Windows Accounts tab lists the Windows user accounts about which SQLsecure was unable to retrieve information when the snapshot was taken. OS Windows accounts are Active Directory users and groups that have permissions on OS objects such as registry keys.

Url.Title: Unavailable Databases
Url.Abstract: Identify unavailable databases The Unavailable Databases tab lists the databases about which SQLsecure was unable to collect SQL Server security data.

Url.Title: View filters for a snapshot
Url.Abstract: View filters for a snapshot The Filter tab lists the collection filters that SQLsecure uses to collect audit data from your registered SQL Server instances and create a snapshot. Each filter rule defines which data, such as permissions on user tables in a specific database, is collected and included in this snapshot. For more information about how filters work, see Use Filters to Specify which Data is Collected.

Url.Title: Viewing Snapshot Properties
Url.Abstract: Viewing snapshot properties The Snapshot Properties window contains detailed information about your snapshot, including:

Url.Title: Security Summary
Url.Abstract: Assess Your Security Model The Security Summary view allows you to check the status of your security policies at the enterprise and SQL Server instance levels. This view includes the overall policy status, a security report card that lists security risks, the settings of each of your SQL Server instances, and the associated user accounts.

Url.Title: Select audit data for assessment
Url.Abstract: Select audit data for assessment Use the Select Audit Data window to change which audit data (snapshots) the selected policy is using to perform the assigned security checks. Choosing a different set of audit data may alter the policy findings. After you choose a new data set, SQLsecure updates the policy.

Url.Title: View the Enterprise Security Summary
Url.Abstract: Analyze enterprise security The Enterprise Security Summary displays the status of your security policies at the enterprise level. By default, SQLsecure displays the All Servers policy assessment.

Url.Title: Viewing the Enterprise Security Report Card
Url.Abstract: View Enterprise Report Card The Enterprise Security Report Card lists the security check findings for all SQL Server instances that have been assigned to the selected policy.

Url.Title: Viewing the Enterprise Settings
Url.Abstract: View settings across all servers The Settings tab lists the security settings collected for all SQL Server instances associated with this policy. By default, SQLsecure sorts this data by setting name. To sort by instance name, click By Server in the grid menu bar.

Url.Title: Viewing the Enterprise Users
Url.Abstract: View user security across all serverss The Users tab allows you to view all the user accounts associated with the SQL Server instances assigned to the selected policy.

Url.Title: View the Server Security Summary
Url.Abstract: Analyze server security The Server Security Summary displays the status of your security policies at the instance level. To see the Server Security Summary for a policy, expand the corresponding policy node in Servers in Policy tree, and then select the target SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Viewing the Server Security Report Card
Url.Abstract: View Server Report Card The Server Security Report Card lists the security checks evaluated for the selected SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Viewing the Server Settings
Url.Abstract: View settings on this instance You can view a more detailed list of settings, and edit the way SQLsecure collects data from a SQL Server instance, by double-clicking the SQL Server instance from the By Server list.

Url.Title: Viewing the Server Users
Url.Abstract: View user security on this instance The Users tab allows you to view all the user accounts associated with the selected SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Define policies for custom assessments
Url.Abstract: Define policies for custom assessments Policies are security standards implemented to monitor specific risks on one or more SQL Server instances. SQLsecure uses policies to assess your SQL Server security models by performing specific security checks. Each security check has a default value and associated risk level based on known industry regulations and best-practices. You can add, remove, or edit security checks in any policy.

Url.Title: Use policy templates to harden your security model
Url.Abstract: Use policy templates to harden your security model You can use the built-in Idera and industry standard policy templates to further harden your SQL Server security model. By creating policies from these templates, you can enforce consistent security settings across your enterprise, and proactively assess when and where vulnerabilities exist. You can also customize new policies based on these templates to further address your specific security needs.

Url.Title: Create Policies
Url.Abstract: Add new nolicy The Create Policy wizard allows you to add a custom policy to SQLsecure. As a part of this wizard, you will name the policy, select the security checks and their associated risk levels, assign the SQL Server instances you want to assess, and specify additional internal review notes to include in the Risk Assessment report. When you create a policy, you can choose one of the built-in templates based on known industry regulations and best-practices.

Url.Title: Select the type of policy
Url.Abstract: Select policy template The Select the Policy Template window allows you to choose to create a new policy "from scratch" or base your policy on a built-in template.

Url.Title: Give the policy a name and description
Url.Abstract: Specify policy properties The Name the Policy window allows you to give your policy a name and a description. It is important to give your policies easily identifiable names and provide descriptions that help you select the appropriate policy during audits. The policy name and description can be changed later using the Policy Properties window.

Url.Title: Configure the policy risks
Url.Abstract: Select security checks The Configure the Policy window allows you the define the security checks this policy should use to evaluate your audit data.

Url.Title: Select the SQL Servers to apply the policy to
Url.Abstract: Assign SQL Servers The Assign SQL Servers to the Policy window allows you to choose the registered SQL Server instances you want to audit and add them to the policy you are creating. Each registered SQL Server instance can belong to multiple policies. Later, you can use Audited SQL Servers tab of the Policy Properties window to change which instances belong to this policy. For more information, see Audited SQL Servers.

Url.Title: Create an interview
Url.Abstract: Enter Internal Review Notes Use the Internal Review Notes window to specify text or questions that SQLsecure should include in your Risk Assessment and Assessment Comparison reports.These notes can serve as a questionnaire to be used for manually gathering additional data that may be required in your assessment.

Url.Title: View the summary
Url.Abstract: Review policy summary The Completing SQLsecure New Policy Wizard window lists all the details of the policy you are creating. Click Finish to add your policy to SQLsecure. Your new policy will now display in the Policies tree on the Security Summary where you can see the assigned SQL Server instances and determine their compliance with your policy.

Url.Title: Edit policy settings
Url.Abstract: Edit policy settings The Policy Properties window allows you to quickly edit your policy settings. Changes made on the Policy Properties window are instantly applied to your policy.

Url.Title: Change policy properties
Url.Abstract: Change policy properties The General tab of the Policy Properties window allows you to update the name and description of the selected policy. The policy name appears on the Security Summary window and in the Policies tree.

Url.Title: Change policy security checks
Url.Abstract: Change policy security checks Security checks assess the vulnerability of specific Windows OS and SQL Server objects based on your criteria. After security checks are configured and your SQL Server instances are assigned to the policy, you can view the results on the Security Overview window and on the Risk Assessment Report.

Url.Title: Change SQL Servers audited by policy
Url.Abstract: Change SQL Servers audited by policy The Audited SQL Servers tab allows you to change which registered SQL Server instances are assigned to this policy. You can add or remove instances from this policy to better match your auditing needs. Each registered SQL Server instance can belong to multiple policies.

Url.Title: Change Internal Review Notes in policy
Url.Abstract: Change Internal Review Notes in policy The Internal Review Notes tab allows you to edit the manually-collected data applied to your policy. Manually-collected data is security information that cannot be gathered and assessed through SQLsecure.

Url.Title: Export policies
Url.Abstract: Export policies The Export Policy window allows you to save the currently selected policy as a template to base other policies on. To export your policy, browse to the desired location you want to store your policy template, enter a file name, and click Save.

Url.Title: Import policies
Url.Abstract: Import policies The Import Policy window allows you to choose to either add a policy template or previously exported policy to the Policy tree. Once the policy is selected, you can then configure the policy and select the SQL Server instances to add to the policy.

Url.Title: Policy assessments
Url.Abstract: Policy assessments By creating and comparing policy assessments, you can integrate your SQLsecure policies into your existing audit process.

Url.Title: Save new assessment
Url.Abstract: Save new assessment Use the Save as New Assessment window to create a new assessment that uses the same audit data and settings of an existing assessment. Specify a unique name and description for this new assessment, and then click OK.

Url.Title: Refresh audit data
Url.Abstract: Refresh audit data Use the Refresh Audit Data window to change which audit data (snapshots) this assessment is using to perform the assigned security checks. Choosing a different set of audit data may alter the assessment findings. After you choose a new data set, SQLsecure updates the assessment.

Url.Title: Edit Assessments
Url.Abstract: Edit Assessments Use the Edit Assessment window to change basic properties or how the assessment performs its security evaluation.

Url.Title: Change assessment properties
Url.Abstract: Change assessment properties The General tab of the Assessment Properties window allows you to update the name and description of the selected assessment as well as any notes you want to provide.

Url.Title: Change assessment security checks
Url.Abstract: Change assessment security checks Security checks assess the vulnerability of specific Windows OS and SQL Server objects based on your criteria. The security checks performed by the selected assessment were copied from the policy associated with this assessment. You can modify the criteria of these checks to better fit your auditing needs for this assessment. Changes made to the assessment security checks will not affect the associated policy.

Url.Source: ../Content/SQLsecure Help/Change Internal Review Notes in Assessment.htm
Url.Title: Change Internal Review Notes in assessment
Url.Abstract: Change Internal Review Notes in assessment The Internal Review Notes tab allows you to edit the manually-collected data applied to your assessment. Manually-collected data is security information that cannot be gathered and assessed through SQLsecure.

Url.Title: Edit explanation notes
Url.Abstract: Edit explanation notes Use the Edit Explanation Notes window to add or change the explanation notes associated with this security check. You can specify a different explanation note for each finding on each affected SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Working with draft assessments
Url.Abstract: Working with draft assessments Use draft assessments to fine-tune your data and settings when you begin your audit process.

Url.Title: Working with published assessments
Url.Abstract: Working with published assessments Use published assessments to apprise internal or external auditors of your security status and settings.

Url.Title: Working with approved assessments
Url.Abstract: Working with approved assessments Approved assessments accurately represent your security status at a specific point in time.

Url.Title: View assessment change log
Url.Abstract: View assessment change log The Change Log tab lists all changes that have been made to the selected assessment.

Url.Title: Compare assessments
Url.Abstract: Compare assessments Use the Assessment Comparison window to compare any two assessments saved from the same policy. You can compare assessments previously saved from the default All Servers policy or from any custom policy you created. For example, you may want to compare a draft assessment of this quarter's All Servers audit to an approved assessment of last quarter's All Servers audit.

Url.Title: Compare assessment summaries
Url.Abstract: Compare assessment summaries Use the Compare Summaries tab on the Assessment Comparison window to identify any differences in the security status of the two selected assessments. SQLsecure highlights each difference in yellow, and shows where findings are equal (=) or not equal (≠).

Url.Title: Compare assessment security checks
Url.Abstract: Compare assessment security checks Use the Compare Security Checks tab on the Assessment Comparison window to identify any differences in the security check settings of the two selected assessments. SQLsecure identifies each difference using yellow highlights and bold blue text, and shows where security settings are equal (=) or not equal (≠).

Url.Title: Compare Internal Review Notes
Url.Abstract: Compare Internal Review Notes Use the Compare Internal Review Notes tab on the Assessment Comparison window to identify any differences in the internal review notes associated with the two selected assessments. SQLsecure displays both notes and identifies whether notes are equal (=) or not equal (≠).

Url.Title: Reports
Url.Abstract: Report on SQL Server Security The Reports component of SQLsecure allows you to generate reports on SQL Server permissions. Use reports to confirm regulatory compliance and enforce security policies.

Url.Title: How to use the Deploy Reports wizard
Url.Abstract: How to use the Deploy Reports wizard You can deploy the SQLsecure Reports to your existing Microsoft Reporting Services installation.

Url.Title: Deploy Reports Wizard Connect to Reporting Services
Url.Abstract: Connect to Reporting Services The Connect to Reporting Services tab allows you to specify the Report Server to which you want to deploy the SQLsecure Reports. The Deploy Reports wizard automatically applies connection settings based on a default Microsoft Reporting Services installation. You can use the default connection settings, or specify custom connection settings.

Url.Title: Deploy Reports Wizard SQLsecure Repository
Url.Abstract: Specify Repository as reports data source The SQLsecure Repository tab allows you to specify which Windows user account SQLsecure should use to connect to the Repository. You can use the same account that the Collection Service runs under, or you can specify a different account.

Url.Title: Specify the reports virtual directory
Url.Abstract: Specify the reports virtual directory This Report Deployment Location tab allows you to specify the name of the folder where the reports should be stored. This folder belongs to the Virtual Directory specified in the Reporting Services connection settings, and is displayed when you access the reports using the Report Manager interface.

Url.Title: Deploy Reports Wizard Summary
Url.Abstract: Finish the Reports deployment Review the provided summary, and then click Finish. When you finish this wizard, SQLsecure installs the corresponding RDL files in the specified virtual directory on your Report Server.

Url.Title: Using Quick Reports
Url.Abstract: Use the Console to generate reports SQLsecure includes built-in reports which have been specially designed to generate commonly requested audit reports using the SQL Server permission data collected in your snapshots.

Url.Title: Customizing Reports
Url.Abstract: Use Reporting Services to generate reports SQLsecure includes the ability to take the existing built-in SQLsecure reports and seamlessly integrate them into Microsoft Reporting Services. For each built-in SQLsecure report, the Deploy Reports wizard installs a Report Definition Language (RDL) file. These RDL files define the report layout and parameters, using the data source (SQLsecure Repository) you specified during install. Reporting Services automatically acknowledges these files, allowing you to immediately generate and view reports on audit data using the Reports Manager Web interface.

Url.Title: Using the Manage SQLsecure view
Url.Abstract: Manage SQLsecure The Manage SQLsecure view lets you easily and quickly change your SQLsecure configuration and review SQLsecure activity.

Url.Title: Configure email settings
Url.Abstract: Configure email settings The SMTP Email Provider window allows you to enter your provider information, through which email notifications are distributed.

Url.Title: Delete a data snapshot
Url.Abstract: Delete a Data Snapshot When you no longer want to keep a snapshot (and do not want to wait for the grooming process to occur), right-click the snapshot in the Snapshot window and select Delete snapshot. A confirmation window appears, click Delete to continue.

Url.Title: Configure Audit Settings
Url.Abstract: Edit audited SQL Server properties The Audited SQL Server Properties window allows you to edit the way SQLsecure monitors your SQL Server instances. The Audited SQL Server Properties window contains general SQL Server instance information, snapshot filter settings, and audit data collection schedule.

Url.Title: Audit Filters tab
Url.Abstract: Change audit filters The Filters tab allows you to add a new filter, delete filters, and edit filter properties. Filters are the criteria used when collecting audit data for your snapshots.

Url.Title: Credentials tab
Url.Abstract: Change connection credentials The Credentials tab displays the credentials that SQLsecure uses to access the databases on the selected SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Email tab
Url.Abstract: Change email notification The Email tab allows you to configure the way email notifications are sent after a snapshot is collected. You can select to have email notifications sent after a snapshot is collected successfully, or only if there are warnings or errors. You can also select to have email notifications sent depending on the level of the security risks discovered.

Url.Title: General tab
Url.Abstract: Change general properties The General tab contains basic information about your audited SQL Server, including the instance name, the SQL Server version, snapshot information, and security and auditing information.

Url.Title: Schedule tab
Url.Abstract: Change snapshot schedule The Schedule tab allows you to choose the best times to generate a snapshot on your SQL Server instance.

Url.Title: Policies tab
Url.Abstract: Change which policies audit this instance The Policies tab allows you to modify the policies that the selected SQL Server instance is assigned to.

Url.Title: Manage policies
Url.Abstract: Manage policies Use the Manage Policies view to obtain a quick overview of which policies are enabled and have saved assessments.

Url.Title: Managing your SQLsecure licenses
Url.Abstract: Manage your license SQLsecure provides an intuitive, simple to use interface for license key management. You can view the status of the license keys and add licenses to audit additional instances.

Url.Title: Using the Logins window
Url.Abstract: Manage SQLsecure logins The Logins window allows you to view a list of logins that are active in SQLsecure. This list provides the name, type of login, SQL Server access, and permissions in SQLsecure for each login. From this window, you can add new logins, delete logins, and edit login properties. A user must have a SQLsecure login to use SQLsecure features, such as Reports.

Url.Title: Using the SQLsecure New Login Wizard
Url.Abstract: Add new login The New Login Wizard allows you to add new SQL Server logins to SQLsecure. In this wizard, you will be asked to supply the Windows user account name and level of access for the user you would like to add.

Url.Title: Add a new SQL Server login window
Url.Abstract: Specify login properties The Add a new SQL Server login window allows you to enter the Windows account name of the user you would like to add to SQLsecure. You can also specify whether or not you would like to grant access to this user.

Url.Title: SQLsecure Permissions window
Url.Abstract: Select permissions The Set the SQLsecure Permission level window allows you to choose whether or not the user should have access to SQLsecure and at what level. If the user is given administrator rights to SQLsecure, the login will also be added to the System Administrators role on the SQL Server that hosts the SQLsecure Repository.

Url.Title: Review login summary
Url.Abstract: Review login summary Review the provided summary of the login you are creating, and then click Finish. When you finish this wizard, SQLsecure creates a SQL Server login with the specified permissions on the SQL Server instance that hosts the Repository databases.

Url.Title: Changing SQLsecure login permissions
Url.Abstract: Edit login settings SQLsecure allows you to edit individual login permissions (to SQLsecure) from the Manage SQLsecure view.

Url.Title: Selecting a Server
Url.Abstract: Select audited SQL Server to explore data The Select Audited SQL Server window allows you to select the audited server to use when exploring user and object permissions or when configuring your audit settings. To select a server, click the registered server name and then click OK to continue.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting WMI connectivity issues
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting WMI connectivity issues The user account used by SQLsecure to gather Operation System and Active Directory objects must have administrator permissions on the remote server to be able to use WMI.

Url.Title: Using the SQLsecure Activity window
Url.Abstract: View SQLsecure activity Each time a change or action occurs in SQLsecure, an event is logged. These logged events appear in the SQLsecure Activity view. This log includes collection activity, snapshot configuration changes, SQLsecure login changes, and any other changes made to your SQLsecure settings.

Url.Title: Using the Audited SQL Servers window
Url.Abstract: View the SQLsecure Repository status View the SQLsecure Repository status The Repository Status window allows you to view status of the SQL Server instances that are registered with SQLsecure, SQLsecure licenses, and the SQL Server Agent used for collecting data.

Url.Title: Change Audit Data Settings
Url.Abstract: Change Audit Data Settings The Change Settings button opens the Select Audit Data window. This window allows you to select what data to display in your Security Report Card. By default, Use most current data is selected. To select alternate data, uncheck the Use most current data box and select the date and time of the data you want displayed in the Security Report Card.

Url.Source: ../Content/SQLsecure Help/Change SQL Servers Audited by Assessment.htm
Url.Title: Change SQL Servers audited by assessment
Url.Abstract: Change SQL Servers audited by assessment The Audited SQL Servers tab allows you to change which registered SQL Server instances are assigned to this assessment. You can add or remove instances from this assessment to better match your current auditing needs. Each registered SQL Server instance can belong to multiple assessments.

Url.Title: Configuring SQLsecure
Url.Abstract: Configure SQLsecure You must first register SQL Server instances with SQLsecure, setup your audit filters, and schedule your audits before SQLsecure you can begin auditing your SQL Server instances.

Url.Title: Creating a security policy
Url.Abstract: Creating a security policy SQLsecure uses policies to allow you to specify specific security checks and their associated risk levels. Once configured, SQLsecure will examine your snapshots and display any associated risks on the Security Summary window

Url.Title: Editing audit settings
Url.Abstract: Editing audit settings After you have registered a SQL Server instance with SQLsecure, you may want to go back and change some of the filters and audit collection schedule times.

Url.Title: Find object permissions
Url.Abstract: Find Object Permissions SQL Server database objects can be viewed in the Explore Permissions view. To find all the permissions associated with a particular user:

Url.Title: Product documentation PDF
Url.Abstract: Product documentation PDF Use this PDF to print sections of the SQLsecure product documentation. To download this PDF, click here (requires Adobe Reader).

Url.Title: Reporting Services
Url.Abstract: Reporting Services The Reporting Services window allows you to integrate SQLsecure reports into the Microsoft Reporting Services.

Url.Title: Security Summary
Url.Abstract: Assess Your Security Model The Security Summary view allows you to check the status of your security policies at the enterprise and at the individual monitored SQL Server instance levels. This view includes the overall policy status, a security report card that lists security risks, the settings of each of your SQL Server instances, and the associated user accounts.

Url.Title: Selecting Databases
Url.Abstract: Selecting a Database The Select Database window allows you to select the database you want to analyze permissions on. To select a database, click the database name and then click OK to continue.

Url.Title: Selecting Roles
Url.Abstract: Selecting Roles The Select Role window allows you to select the role you want to analyze permissions on. To select a role, click the role name and then click OK to continue.

Url.Title: Setup snapshot filters
Url.Abstract: Setup Snapshot Filters You can configure data collections from the Explore Permissions view. To configure data collection:

Url.Title: Upgrade Credentials
Url.Abstract: Upgrade Credentials SQLsecure no longer uses the credentials of your SQL Server Agent to collect Operating System and SQL Server security information. This change improves the security model of SQLsecure. If, in a previous version of SQLsecure, it was specified that SQLsecure should use the credentials of the SQL Agent to collect security information, you will have to enter new credentials.
